official-title.#text: To establish a National Flood Research and Education Center to provide research, data, and recommendations on physical science, social science, economic analysis, policy analysis, risk analysis, monitoring, predicting, and planning as they relate to flooding and flood related issues.

committee-name.#tail: , and in addition to the Committee on
committee-name.#text: Committee on Science, Space, and Technology

committee-name.#tail: , for a period to be subsequently determined by the Speaker, in each case for consideration of such provisions as fall within the jurisdiction of the committee concerned

cosponsor.#tail: ) introduced the following bill; which was referred to the

short-title.#text: National Flood Research and Education Center Act

text.#text: This Act may be cited as the

header.#text: National Flood Research and Education Center establishment and purpose

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.@value: National Flood Research and Education Center
{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#text: National Flood Research and Education Center

text.#text: There is established within the
an office within the

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail: (in this Act referred to as the
{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#text: Administrator of the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration

text.#text: one public university or college selected by the

quote.#tail: ), which shall serve as the lead partner institution with the

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail: and the lead partner institution based on their ability to fulfill specific purposes of

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.@value: National Flood Research and Education Center

text.#text: a consortium of other public universities or colleges selected by the

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.@value: National Flood Research and Education Center

text.#text: The purposes of

To plan, conduct, and arrange for competent public research, data, education, and recommendations within the following categories as they relate to flooding issues nationwide, regionally, and locally:
Physical sciences, including engineering, hydrology, environmental, and atmospheric sciences, of flooding and flood-related events.
Social science of flooding and flood-related events focused on increasing community resilience.

Economic analysis of flooding and flood-related events in addition to analysis of a variety of existing and new strategies and techniques to reduce, manage, and prevent flooding and flood-related events.
Policy analysis and recommendations on flooding-related policy on a Federal, State, and local governmental basis.
Risk analysis and risk management of flooding and flood-related events.
Improvement of existing, and testing of new, risk assessment tools, methods, and models for flooding and flood risks used by Federal, State, and local governments and other interested organizations.
Improvement of existing, and testing of new, monitoring and predicting strategies and techniques of flooding and flood-related events.
Improvement of existing, and testing of new, flood management and prevention strategies and techniques.

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail: based on their specific flooding and flood-related issues, hydrology, weather, and related issues so that diverse flood situations are represented and examined through
{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.@value: National Flood Research and Education Center
National Flood Research and Education Center

text.#text: To carry out this Act within a variety of regions in the United States which are identified and categorized by

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.@value: National Flood Research and Education Center

text.#text: To identify opportunities for increased efficiency in allocation of resources, coordination, cooperation, and consolidation of efforts as they relate to local, Statewide, regional, and Federal flood-related efforts with respect to

To develop or improve undergraduate and graduate degree programs and other programs at the consortium-member public universities and colleges to advance the entry of new talent into flooding-related fields.

To collaborate with other colleges and universities in the region that have demonstrated capability for research, information dissemination, and graduate training in order to develop regional networks that are knowledgeable on regional flooding issues.

text.#text: In addition, the lead partner institution shall publish annually a report specific to its activities, partnerships and collaborations, State and local policy recommendations, previous and continuing budgets, findings, and other applicable information by a date determined by the

The consortium members shall each publish annually a report containing the activities, partnerships and collaborations, State and local policy recommendations, previous and continuing budgets, findings, and other applicable information by a date determined by the lead partner institution which shall also be made available to the public in an easily accessible electronic format on the consortium members’ websites.

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail: may provide technical assistance and demonstration project grant assistance to eligible entities on a competitive basis to assist with implementing recommendations of
{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.@value: National Flood Research and Education Center

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail: or testing new or improved strategies or technologies for the categories described in

National Flood Research and Education Center Act/s:2/ss:b/p:1

text.#text: The following are eligible entities for purposes of this section:
State governments.
County governments.
Local governments.

Consortium members may provide technical assistance at their discretion to eligible entities that have limited capacity for developing an application for demonstration project grants. Consortium members may also provide technical assistance at their discretion in implementing demonstration projects approved by the

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail: , in partnership with the lead partner institution, shall develop criteria required for submitting a competitive demonstration project grant application and for the approval of such an application.

text.#text: The

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.@value: National Flood Research and Education Center

text.#text: Grantees may use funds only for flooding-related projects which implement recommendations of
improved existing and or new risk analysis and risk management of flooding and flood-related events;
improved existing and or new risk assessment tools, methods, and models for flooding and flood risks used by Federal, State, and local governments and other interested organizations;
improved existing and or new monitoring and predicting strategies and techniques of flooding and flood related events; or
improved existing and or new flood management and prevention strategies and techniques.
Eligible entities may subcontract a portion of grant funds received for necessary construction-related costs to pursue an eligible activity.

Within 60 days of receiving a completed application, the consortium member in whose region the project will take place and the lead partner institution shall review and approve or disapprove the application.

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail: shall determine whether to provide the project final approval.

text.#text: Within 30 days of receiving an application that has been approved by the applicable consortium members, the
Demonstration project grant awards under this section shall not exceed $250,000 per project.

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail: may waive such grant size limitation if—

text.#text: The
all consortium members approve of such a waiver;
the eligible entity has the expertise, or will work with partners that have the expertise, to manage the proposed project; and

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.@value: National Flood Research and Education Center

text.#text: the eligible entity can show that a project involves multiple watersheds or jurisdictions, benefits multiple communities, has broad community support, and incorporates multiple aspects of
Entities receiving a demonstration project grant under this section shall be required to provide a 30 percent non-Federal cost share.
There shall be not more than $2,000,000 available annually for demonstration project grants under this section nationwide.

header.#text: Total Demonstration Project Grant Amount Available

text.#text: For a demonstration project that receives a grant under this section, the applicable regional consortium member shall monitor the effectiveness, efficiency, and progress of the project and report on these factors and their involvement periodically to the lead partner institution. The applicable regional consortium member shall make this information available through its website and additionally provide this information in its annual reports.

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#text: For each of the fiscal years 2014 through 2019, there are authorized

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.@value: National Flood Research and Education Center

text.#text: not more than $2,000,000 each fiscal year shall be for the operation of the
not more than $3,000,000 each fiscal year shall be for the operation of the lead partner institution’s center, matched by a 20 percent non-Federal cost share.
There are authorized such sums as may be necessary for the lead partner institution to improve its facilities to a level that meets the requirements of the role of lead partner institution.

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail: . Such plan shall include any land acquisition, engineering, design, and staffing and equipment needs, in addition to other information as required by the

text.#text: Before the lead partner institution receives any funding under this subsection, a plan detailing what type of facility construction or improvements will take place must first be approved by the
There shall be a non-Federal cost share of 20 percent for facility improvement or construction projects pursued by the lead partner institution.
Any authorized and funded construction activity shall meet Federal prevailing wage requirements as determined by the

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#text: subchapter IV of chapter 31 of part A of subtitle II of title 40, United States Code
{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.@value: usc-chapter/40/31/IV
Davis-Bacon Act

text.#text: Not more than $3,000,000 each fiscal year shall be for the operation of all consortium members’ centers, matched by a 20 percent non-Federal cost share.
Any one consortium member shall not receive more than $500,000 in Federal funds in one fiscal year.
Not more than $2,000,000 each fiscal year shall be made available for demonstration project grants nationwide.
